comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Social Documentary Photography & events, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group.

comment.author: 23393335@N06
comment._content: Has this field been planted yet? I see grass/weeds that they are 'chopping' but no cotton. One of the earlier photos shows some plant, I assume cotton, a few inches high in rows that the people are working around with hoes but not here and they should be high enough to show up. Is this just a very labor-intensive way to prepare last years ground for the new planting?

comment.author: 14953288@N00
comment._content: They probably couldn't afford any major pieces of equipment.  It was a cheap but labor intensive tillage method involving chopping down the old cotton plant stalks and turning any plant material under the soil surface.

comment.author: 21729315@N00
comment._content: Looks like sugarcane forground left side....

comment.author: 45385360@N00
comment._content: I am noting the even distribution of labor. No glass ceiling here.

comment.author: 37817855@N00
comment._content: I'm pretty sure Jack posed them---you can tell by their faces and posturing.  You know how old war photographers used to prop up dead soldiers in strange positions to make the death photo more aesthetic?  It's like that, I think.
